text:
I’ve seen people cry after a rejection.
Not because they didn’t get the job…
But because the process broke them.

– Ghosted after 6 rounds.
– No feedback after weeks of effort.
– False promises about salary, role, and growth.

Every job seeker deserves dignity.
Because behind every application is a story:
– A fresh graduate supporting their family.
– A laid-off employee trying to rebuild.
– A parent who just wants stability for their kids.

A simple ‘Thank you, we appreciate your time’ can bring hope.
A little empathy can bring healing.

HR is not just about filling roles.
It’s about shaping lives.
Please don’t forget the human in human resources.

You didn’t get rejected because you’re not good enough.
You didn’t get ghosted because your skills are weak.
You didn’t get that “We’ll get back to you” mail because you lacked effort.

The truth is:
* Many job postings already have someone in mind.
* Many interviews are just for compliance.
* Many “recruitment processes” are designed to exploit hope, not talent.

But here’s what they can’t take away from you:
✔ Your skills that you’ve built brick by brick.
✔ Your resilience that kept you going despite rejections.
✔ Your fire to grow, even when the world is unfair.

To every job seeker reading this:
You are not your rejection mail.
You are not “we found someone else.”
You are proof that courage exists in human form.

One “yes” is all it takes.
And it’s coming your way. 💙

If you’re looking, comment “open to work” – let’s create visibility (along with the role that you're looking for)

If you’re hiring, please drop opportunities below – you might just change someone’s life today.

A recent survey found that 68% of job seekers applied to roles that were never actively hiring.
Another report revealed that over 40% of job postings online are “ghost jobs.”

Why do companies do this?

To look like they are growing (good for investors).
To build a candidate pipeline they’ll never call.
To make employees think “we are hiring, so business is great.”
Sometimes just to collect free resumes for future reference.

But the impact?

70% of candidates report feeling “demotivated” when they realize the job was never real.
People waste hours applying, editing resumes, and preparing for nothing.
It worsens the already fragile mental health of job seekers.

Ghost hiring isn’t just unethical - it’s cruel.
When hope is given without intention, it becomes exploitation.

If you’ve ever refreshed your inbox waiting for a reply that never comes - you’re not alone.

And if you’re a company doing this? Remember: reputation is harder to rebuild than a candidate pipeline.

Job seekers deserve honesty. Not illusions.

Respect.
A word we all use, but don’t always mean the same way.

For some, respect means treating someone like a human being.
For others, respect means treating someone like an authority.

The real issue?
When people in power say:
“ If you don’t respect me, I won’t respect you.”

But what they actually mean is:
“ If you don’t treat me like an authority, I won’t treat you like a person.”

And that’s dangerous.
Because everyone deserves to be treated like a person - no matter their title, position, or power.

Respect should never be conditional on hierarchy.
It should be the bare minimum of humanity.

LinkedIn reach these days be like:

You post your heart, your soul, and a sprinkle of your sanity...
…and LinkedIn shows it to exactly 3 people.

One of them is your mom.

The other is you (because you went back to check the likes).

And the last is that one guy from your last job who never liked you but still stalks you.

Moral of the story:
At this point, I think I’m writing a personal diary here.

I commented “Congrats!” on someone else’s post - got more views than my own post.
